title: 107_s1444
content: The Act titled "Federal Air Marshals and Safe Sky Act of 2001" establishes a program. The Act titled "Federal Air Marshals and Safe Sky Act of 2001" establishes a Federal air marshals program under Chapter 37 of title 28, United States Code. This program aims to enhance security at airports and on commercial aircraft. The "Federal Air Marshals and Safe Sky Act of 2001" establishes a Federal Air Marshals program under Chapter 37 of title 28, United States Code to provide maximum security at airports and on board commercial aircraft. The program includes Federal Air Marshals and Deputy Federal Air Marshals for this purpose. The Federal Air Marshals program enforces federal laws regulating airport and aircraft security, including laws on terrorism, hijacking, and disruptive passenger behavior. The Attorney General deputizes retired military personnel as Deputy Federal Air Marshals to assist Federal Air Marshals. The Attorney General can employ retired military and law enforcement personnel as Deputy Federal Air Marshals, compensating them through various methods authorized by law. The Attorney General can employ retired military and law enforcement personnel as Deputy Federal Air Marshals, compensating them through methods authorized by law. The program requires consultation with appropriate officials and certification, training, and examination of air marshals. Federal Air Marshals and Deputy Federal Air Marshals have the authority to arrest individuals suspected of violating Federal laws related to airport security. The powers of Federal Air Marshals and Deputy Federal Air Marshals are limited to enforcing Federal laws related to security at airports or on board aircraft. They are not granted the power to enforce any other Federal laws, and their authority does not limit that of other law enforcement officers. The Attorney General is responsible for creating regulations to implement this section. The program costs will be shared by airlines, state and local governments, and the Federal Government. Appropriations are authorized as necessary to implement this section. The Federal share of program costs under this section is limited to the cost after payments by airlines, states, and local governments. SEC. 3. REPEAL. Section 44903 of title 49, United States Code, is repealed. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and the amendments made by this Act shall take effect 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
